Name: KIParla - Corpus of Spoken Italian
Publisher/Promoter: Developed collaboratively by the Universities of Bologna and Turin.
Size: The corpus comprises over 150 hours of recorded conversations, totaling approximately 1,144,067 tokens.
Format: The dataset includes audio recordings aligned with their transcriptions. Transcriptions are available in both orthographic and simplified conversational formats, accessible through the NoSketch Engine interface.
Source and Context: Data were collected from various communicative situations, including semi-structured interviews, spontaneous conversations, table discussions, lectures, exams, and student receptions. Recordings were made in multiple Italian cities, notably Bologna and Turin.
Type of Speech: The corpus encompasses a range of speech types such as conversational, monologues, spontaneous, and read speech.
Regional Varieties: Includes speakers from diverse Italian regions, capturing various dialects and idiomatic expressions.
Sociolinguistic Variations: Features participants of different ages, genders, educational backgrounds, and socio-economic statuses. Age, gender, level of education are mapped. Ages span from 16 to over 85.
Multilingual Corpus: Primarily focuses on Italian but may include instances of code-switching or influence from other languages due to Italy's linguistic diversity.
Data Collection: Recordings were conducted overtly, with all participants providing informed consent in compliance with European data protection regulations. All data have been collected by professional researchers and trained students and interns of the universities involved.
Participant Selection: Participants were selected based on criteria such as age, gender, regional origin, and educational background to ensure a representative sample. Ages span from 16 to over 85.
Transcription Standard: Employed a simplified version of the Jefferson system, commonly used in conversation analysis.
Annotation Levels: Transcriptions include lexical, syntactic, and prosodic annotations.
Tools and Software Used: Transcriptions were created using ELAN software, facilitating alignment with audio recordings.
Quality Control and Validation: Data underwent anonymization and were reviewed for accuracy and consistency. Sensitive information was replaced or covered in both transcripts and audio files.
Availability: The corpus is accessible online through the NoSketch Engine interface. Data downloaded via the platform are shared under the Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 4.0 license.
Other: The corpus is designed for incremental modularity, allowing for future additions and updates to enhance its scope and representativeness.

Name: MSPKA - Multi-Speaking-Style-Articulatory Corpus
Publisher/Promoter: Robotics, Brain and Cognitive Sciences Department, Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia, Genova, Italy / Claudia Canevari, Leonardo Badino, Luciano Fadiga
Size: Session 1 includes over 500 Italian sentences, totaling approximately 2 hours of speech data.
Format: Simultaneous recordings of audio and articulatory data using Electromagnetic Articulography (EMA).
Source and Context: Sentences selected from popular novels and web texts to provide balanced phonetic coverage and diverse speech registers.

Participant Selection: Three native Italian speakers selected to provide a balanced phonetic dataset.
Transcription Standard: Phonetic transcription using the Italian letter-to-sound tool for the Festival Speech Synthesis System; phone boundaries estimated and manually checked.
Annotation Levels: Phonetic transcriptions with phone boundaries.
Tools and Software Used: NDI Wave speech electromagnetic articulography system, Festival Speech Synthesis System, HTK, PRAAT.
Quality Control and Validation: Manual checking of phone boundaries to ensure accuracy.
Availability: Freely available for research purposes at http://www.mspkacorpus.it.
References: Canevari, C., Badino, L., & Fadiga, L. (2015). 'A new Italian dataset of parallel acoustic and articulatory data.' In *Proceedings of Interspeech 2015* (pp. 2152-2156). https://www.isca-archive.org/interspeech_2015/canevari15_interspeech.pdf
